error.signature: psycopg2.OperationalError: could not connect to server: Connection refused
error.regex: could not connect to server.*Connection refused

verdict.summary: PostgreSQL server is not running or not listening on the expected host/port. Most commonly caused by the service being stopped, misconfigured listen_addresses, or firewall rules blocking port 5432.

dead_ends.action: Reinstalling the PostgreSQL client library (psycopg2) to fix the connection error
dead_ends.why_fails: The error is a server-side connectivity issue, not a client library bug. Reinstalling psycopg2 does not affect whether the PostgreSQL server is reachable.

dead_ends.action: Changing the connection string encoding or SSL mode without verifying the server is actually running
dead_ends.why_fails: If the server process is not running or not listening on the target port, no amount of connection parameter tweaking will establish a connection.

workarounds.action: Start the PostgreSQL service and verify it is listening on the correct port
workarounds.how: Run 'sudo systemctl start postgresql' (or 'pg_ctl start -D /var/lib/postgresql/16/main'). Verify with 'ss -tlnp | grep 5432' or 'pg_isready -h localhost -p 5432'.

workarounds.action: Check and update listen_addresses in postgresql.conf to bind to the correct interface
workarounds.how: Edit postgresql.conf and set listen_addresses = '*' (or the specific IP). Restart PostgreSQL. Also ensure pg_hba.conf allows connections from the client IP.

leads_to.condition: when server starts but pg_hba.conf requires password authentication

preceded_by.condition: when PostgreSQL crashes due to disk full and fails to restart

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Connection refused means the server is not listening at all, while too many connections means the server is running but has hit max_connections limit.
